Dear Sirs,

Re: Complaint against Ho Kwan Yiu

I am writing to make a complaint against Mr. HO KWAN YIU ("Mr. Ho") for his vulgarity, distasteful comment and potential sexual harassment through a public commentary platform. Mr. Ho has delivered misleading legal comment implying sexual harassment will not apply to male victims, but only female victims. Such comment also implies sex discrimination towards males in a sexual harassment case. It is a shame to learn that he is a solicitor qualified in Hong Kong.

On 9 August 2019, Mr. Ho published a post in facebook. A netizen responded to him asking him to give himself up to the police. Mr. Ho responded and asked the netizen to go masturbating (「妳自慰啦」). In response to an enquiry from a journalist of the newspaper Hong Kong 01, Mr. Ho said "there was no sexual harassment to cockroaches, let alone we are not sure whether the person is a female or male. 「對曱甴是沒有性騷擾嘅！況且大家都唔知佢喺公定乸！」)(https://www.hk01.com/%E6%94%BF%E6%83%85/362154/%E6%94%BF%E5%A3%87%E8%AB%B8%E4%BA%8B%E7%94%BA-%E5%8F%AB%E5%A5%B3%E7%B6%B2%E6%B0%91-%E8%87%AA%E6%85%B0-%E8%A2%AB%E6%8C%87%E6%80%A7%E9%A8%B7%E6%93%BE-%E4%BD%95%E5%90%9B%E5%A0%AF%E5%88%AA%E6%8B%92%E9%81%93%E6%AD%89%E8%B2%BC%E6%96%87?fbclid=IwAR1hnEgL_bnpyi3egFwf71D11W-rpMbNTOgDDU8MaDniDvCyRZmamNuNfcg)

Reference is made to a disciplinary case against Tse Wai Chun Paul ("Mr. Tse") by the Law Society in 2003/2004 for breach of Principle 1.02 of the Hong Kong Solicitors' Guide to Professional Conduct. In that case, Mr. Tse on one occasion, stood demonstrating in the street wearing no clothes other than his swimming trunks. Mr. Tse held a banner covering his lower part with a template that stated in both English and Chinese 'Legal rights are inborn mine too'. The Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal found that the complaints against Mr. Tse was proved that, among others, Mr. Tse conducted himself in a manner likely to bring the profession into disrepute in breach of Principle 1.02 of the Hong Kong Solicitors' Guide to Professional Conduct in respect of the demonstration.

For the present case, Mr. Ho was widely reported as a solicitor, and was widely recognised by the public partly due to the fact that he was a past president in the law society. Therefore, his vulgar and irresponsible conduct clearly compromises / impair his own integrity, reputation, and more importantly, the reputation of the profession.

His conduct is in clear breach of Rule 2 of Solicitors’ Practice Rules, which states that:-
“A solicitor shall not, in the course of practising as a solicitor, do or permit to be done on his behalf anything which compromises or impairs or is likely to compromise or impair—
(a)his independence or integrity;
….
(d)his own reputation or the reputation of the profession…”

In the circumstances, Mr. Ho should be deemed unfit to be a solicitor and should be subject to disciplinary action from the Law Society. I believe that it is also in the best interest of Hong Kong, as well as the legal profession for the Law Society of Hong Kong to openly condemn and criticise such misconduct by one of its members.

Your prompt reply would be greatly appreciated.

Yours truly,
xxx
